reviews.review: For an FPS that is almost a decade old, its serviceable. Visually, this game looks great, more so when considering its release date. It isn't perfect though, and I know which BioShock is my favourite. Its still worth a visit though.
I want Elizabeth to be my girlfriend

Whilst a short game (finished in 12 hours on hard) its a game i'll never forget, an awesome story, action & environment. I still play the plot out in my head years on.

Look, it's a good shooter, but it's a terrible BioShock game.
All the immersive-sim elements of BioShock were struck from the gameplay.
Story is cool if a little wankery at times.

Todo mundo que jÃ¡ jogou ficou apaixonado por ela, vc tÃ¡ me julgando agora mas depois que jogar vai entender).
BioShock Infinite Ã© um daqueles jogos que, para quem prioriza boas histÃ³rias, vai fazer parte de sua vida e provavelmente retornarÃ¡ anos depois com um sentimento de nostalgia. E para quem prioriza a gameplay, Ã© um jogo divertido de meter bala nos inimigos e soltar poderzinho com uns efeitos legais em lugares bonitos.

The best story i've ever experienced

I'm truly baffled and tired of seeing positive reviews for this stain on the Bioshock series so I'll give my two cents. I took the time recently to go through the Bioshock collection including Minerva's Den and was pleasantly surprised at the quality and care that was taken to ensure that the first two games in the series were as good as they could be. Then I got to this game and was unpleasantly let down HARD. I do not understand the amount of people who played the first two games including Minerva's Den in their entirety and then get to this game and think this game is as good or even BETTER than it's predecessors, it ASTOUNDS me beyond belief. Even if you try to view this game as a standalone it's subpar at best. I find it hard to believe anyone with a modicum of brain function can sit through this and genuinely say they enjoyed this snoozefest. I'll start with the gameplay first because trying to wrap my head around the story and put it into words right now on how absolutely horrendous and brain hemorrhaging it is after finishing it recently will strain my patience more so than it already was while playing this dumpster fire of a game.

Gameplay: For starters, This is LITERALLY a COD campaign, you are paying for a COD campaign with the Bioshock title slapped on it. Everything about the first two games is thrown right out the window, you no longer have your own guns that you can carry with you to change on the fly with unique ammo types meant to deal with different enemy types, instead you're forced to scavenge for other guns when you inevitably run out of ammo. Although, to be fair, I did carry the same carbine and sniper up until about the end of Comstock's house chapter. Did I mention there's a TWO weapon limit by the way? As opposed to the collection of weapons you carried in the first two and their versatility in combat. The weapon upgrades also work differently in this game and honestly for the worse. I don't mind not being to upgrade all the weapons but there are thirteen weapons in this game each having four upgrades to go through, a lot of them being completely useless as well because they either don't really make a difference because the gun was already fine without it or you will just never use that gun. I never once, aside from times where I just wanted to test them out, used the Vox weapons because they are downgrades of the weapons used by the Founders' soldiers. You find yourself going through the game buying ammo for the two weapons you have at every vending machine you see or swapping between the same four weapons because the other weapons are just that bad and not worth using. The vigors are this game's version of plasmids but honestly they're a downgrade as well, I found myself using the flame vigor the most because the counterparts for everything else was so completely garbage and useless in the middle of combat outside of a few situational moments or just used up too much of your salts to actually be effective. You also don't carry your own medkits or salts to recharge your vigor uses, instead you have to rely on drops scattered around an area or wait for Elizabeth to see that you're low and hopefully throw you the item you need the most. I almost forgot to mention the shield. I played on medium so I didn't really see a big problem with it. It's pretty insignificant without the infusion upgrades and it's really just a buffer between your health getting shredded instantly but I've heard on hard it's pretty much useless and just a way to take a single bullet while you poke out of cover to shoot at enemies and repeat the process until everything on the screen is dead. This game's equivalent to gene tonics was pretty underwhelming as well and it takes the form of "gear" which you can only equip four of at a time in certain slots for each. Your health, salt and shield upgrades take form in infusions which are scattered around the map and pretty hard to miss if you aren't exploring the already limited map or can't use your brain and you can fully max two out of three upgrades. Truthfully, salt upgrades are useless and you should be going for health and shield upgrades first. 

Story: Honestly, I don't even want to get in depth with the story, just watch an unbiased review, my patience for this game has been expended. This story is full of plot holes and unanswered questions lined with pseudo-intellectualism, convoluted dimension hopping and time travel. It physically hurts my brain to even think about it's so obnoxious, it amazes me a group of people sat down and decided this was the best story they could come up with. It feels the need to beat you over the head with the story at every turn instead of letting the world tell the story itself like in the first two. There are  points in the game where Elizabeth has to lockpick a door with a lock that doesn't even need to have a lock on it and is literally only there so the game can dump exposition on you, I called them exposition doors. In fact, it isn't even always doors, the game will just randomly stop you from playing the game to dump some more of the story on you. You can think about the story and the events that happen for a few seconds and it falls apart at the seams.

As for the story DLC, it is absolutely a slog to push yourself through. The Burial at Sea EP 1 plays basically the same as the base game except you can carry more than 1 gun for whatever reason now, that being said it is still incredibly boring and almost feels like Bioshock 1 again but falls flat on it's face for almost every reason the base game did. EP 2 however is a STEALTH SECTION, the ENTIRE GAME is a STEALTH SECTION and it is as scuffed as it sounds. This DLC also retcons the entire series, so if you enjoyed the world and story of the first two games and all they that stood for, this DLC is here to bring that crashing down for you.

This game and it's DLC are an absolute bastardization of this series. I cannot express this enough that this game is not even worth getting on sale, save your money for something else and just play the first two games or watch someone else play through this dog vomit. Please, don't touch this game with a 10 ft pole. I wouldn't even wish this game on my worst enemy.

As a huge fan of the first two Bioshock games + Minerva's Den, Bioshock Infinite is an enigma in terms of story and gameplay. It truly boggles my mind that 8-9 years after it's initial release the game has an overall overwhelmingly positive rating on Steam. Each time I've played Bioshock 1, Bioshock 2, and Minerva's Den, I've enjoyed myself thoroughly. Yeah sometimes the flaws are more noticeable on subsequent playthroughs, but those flaws did not detract from my overall enjoyment of those games. Bioshock Infinite, however, has only gotten worse and worse with each subsequent playthrough, and with Burial at Sea, just shits on the legacy of the first two games and what they stood for.

The gameplay for Infinite is a downgrade in every aspect imaginable. Those who have played through all three Bioshock games and claim that Infinite has the best gameplay out of all of them, respectfully, you guys are on drugs. First off, Infinite has a shield system and two weapon limit. That is garbage. Here's why.

In the first two bioshock games, you carried 8 weapons, 7 of which can have multiple ammo types. Those games wanted you to not only use all your weapons at your disposal, but to experiment and see which ammo type is best against certain enemies (although things like armor piercing rounds and anti-personnel rounds are self-explanatory). In Infinite, being limited to two weapons GREATLY reduces the need to experiment and vary your play style. Not only that, but when you run out of ammo, you are forced to pick up weapons off the ground. Why is this a bad thing? Well, Infinite carries over the weapon upgrade system from the previous games. But again, you're limited to two God damn weapons. So, when you run out of ammo for your good weapons, you have to pick up weapons that are, more often than not, not upgraded and therefore completely useless in combat. This issue is compounded on Hard and 1999 modes, where enemies are incredibly spongy, while you are a wet noddle get shot at in multiple directions.

On top of all that, the weapon pool is plagued with useless variants of the base weapons, so more often than not, you're gonna be holding onto two, maybe 3 or four weapons MAX for the entirety of the game. And when you run out of ammo, tough shit. You either have to wait for Elizabeth's dumb AI to hand you ammo, or pick up an UNUPGRADED gun off an enemy and pray you can survive until the end of the encounter. Why limit the player to two weapons, all the while having the weapon pool so bloated that half the time defeated enemies won't even drop ammo for the guns you are carrying? 

To emphasize how much even further of a downgrade the gameplay is, the shield system is some of the worst I've seen. Even on normal difficulty, the shield might as well be made of paper. And the upgrades you find over the course of the game do not help in making it useful, as by the end of the game even at max upgrades, the shield BARELY takes any damage for the player. Why not give the player extra med packs and salts like in the first two game? I know the game was made around the time CoD was huge, but to go so far as to copy it's mechanics to the detriment of the gameplay is so asinine.

The vigors in the game are also un-inspired. I'm not gonna pretend the plasmids in Bioshock 1 and 2 were masterpieces, some of them were kinda useless and others fell into the same type of attack. But it's like they didn't even try with Infinite. Out of the 8 vigors the player will use, 4 of them are stuns. At the very least in the first two games, you aren't required to get all plasmids and have them equipped. In Infinite, since all 8 are equipped at once, the overlap is more noticeable.

And the story... oh boy. I truthfully believe Ken Levine just said "screw it" halfway through development and just gave up. With the way the story plays out, you'd think it was written by a bunch of monkeys wielding typewriters. The story in the first game was something special, and while the 2nd game's story was weaker, it was still a very good, more personal story, with Minerva's Den being the peak of the series for me. Infinite's story was just a bunch of smoke and mirrors, with the story writers waving their hands in front of the player's face while shoving a bunch of pseudo-science down their throat. It tries to be deep and complex, but if you even THINK about the story for more than a second it completely falls apart. Hell, the ending of the base game was such a colossal mess that Burial at Sea Episodes 1 & 2 were made to circumvent the huge, gaping plothole it made. We will get to that plot hole later.

Yeah, at first the story is simple enough, Booker is sent to Columbia to wipe his gambling debt, and all he has to do is bring Elizabeth back with him. However, the moment the player goes through Fink Industries and open another tear into an alternate timeline is where the story drops HARD. One mission to find a gunsmith for a rebel faction single-handedly ruined the game's story, as Booker and Elizabeth open not one but TWO tears into two alternate timelines. Even then, the timeline the story falls into, where Booker is a martyr for the Vox Populi, also doesn't make sense because Comstock, the villain in this game, somehow KNOWS Booker and Elizabeth, even though they were from another timeline. Hell, Comstock doesn't even mention his Elizabeth from his timeline, so like, HUH???

And the ending, OH BOY. The ending of this god forsaken game states that there are infinite universes with infinite possibilities. "Constants and variables." Yeah, infinite universes, bit of an asspull, but that's not all. Elizabeth shows Booker all of the events that has happened prior to the start of the game, him retaining a huge gambling debt, him selling his daughter, Anna (A.K.A Elizabeth), to Comstock, etc. Elizabeth then concludes that Comstock and Booker are one in the same, but in alternate timelines. The cutoff point was when Booker attends a baptism to wash away the guilt he's been carrying with him from the Wounded Knee Massacre. So, two timelines, two Bookers. Ok, simple enough. Elizabeth also concludes that to prevent Comstock from ever existing, the original Booker (the player) must die so that those timelines and universes do not come to be. This would make sense... if the game wasn't shoving the idea of MULTIPLE UNIVERSES down your throat for the duration of the ending. There is no way killing ONE Booker off can erase Comstock's existence, when the GAME ITSELF says "Hey, there an INFINITE amount of you Booker." It's such a slap in the face to the player's intelligence, this whole story is a slap in the face in general. Burial At Sea was made because the dev team knew how much a gaping plothole the base game's ending made, and how couldn't they with the number of reviews on the internet stating how much of a mess it was.

I've had this game in the back of my mind ever since it first released. I liked it when I first played it, but I definitely thought it was a downgrade compared to the first two. Now? I absolutely loathe this game. I don't know how people can play the first two Bioshock games, then play this one and say it's the best. I mentioned Ken Levine in this review, and here I go again. A lot of the development issues Infinite has faced was due to him removing a lot of material from the game, a lot of cut ideas were lost to time and were only shown off in the few gameplay demos before release. Since Infinite, he's the head of his own game development team. And sincerely, I am GLAD he is not part of the development for the rumored Bioshock 4. And considering the recent controversy with him and how he's handling his dev team, I am praying Bioshock 4 will bring back what I loved from the first two games and leave Infinite behind for what it is: a massive disappointment and a tumor on the Shock series.

Much like it's predecessor, the original Bioshock, this game is an absolute masterpiece.  Bioshock Infinite set the bar for the introduction of musical performances & symphonic sounds that drive a video game's story.  

This game *needs* a modern sequel, & it *needs* to be in VR.
j u e g a s o

Sinceramente una obra maestra,la trama que tiene y los temas que toca son increibles
altamente recomendado
This is one of the best single player games i've ever played in my life, everyone should buy it. Amazing story, music, gameplay. Make sure to play the dlc as well

I absolutely loved the first two Bioshocks and I came into this one with a Bioshock sized gap in my heart that needed filling and perhaps the experience I received wasn't the one I was expecting, and I must confess at first I wasn't sure if I liked it, but OUH did it catch up. Despite the save system and some other mechanics being different in this game, it was purely one of the best games I've played in a long time. The ending caught me off guard, yes, but the game itself was absolutely amazing. 11/10.

Leaving this review years after actively playing. This game left a lasting impression on me. The characters, the story line are so immersive that you feel like you've lived in Columbia. I have'nt played a game since this where the story line was as good. Give it a go, you wont regret it.

I am so glad i gave this game a try. The story, atmosphere, music and characters made this a an experience like nothing i have seen before. I haven`t played many games of this genre and didnt think i would enjoy the gameplay as much as i did. It felt satisfying and rewarding. After finishing this game i went and played the original Bioshock and then Burial at Sea. The way they connected these two worlds was brilliant. I would highly recommend both the main game and the DLC.
